column1: Representative ACT-Guided prompts used in ACT-ChatGPT aligned with the six core ACT Processes

column3: Prompt Content

column1: 1. Acceptance: Embracing all aspects of human experience, whether positive or negative.
column3: Please explain the “Tug of War with a Monster” metaphor used in Acceptance and Commitment Therapy. (Answer within 100 words)

I am currently undergoing life reconstruction after a spinal cord injury, including physical training, strength training, and daily living training. Please provide two questions to help me examine whether I am struggling against my internal feelings. (Each question within 50 words)
What is the meaning of accepting the existence of the “monster”? (Answer within 100 words)

Please provide examples of situations in which individuals with spinal cord injury may experience “clean” emotions (direct sensory experiences of an event) and “muddy” emotions (excessive judgment about an event) in ACT. (Each answer within 100 words)
Why is it important to learn to distinguish between “clean” and “muddy” emotions? (Answer within 5 lines)

Please list four scenarios—without telling me the answers directly—to test whether I can distinguish between “clean” emotions (direct sensory experiences) and “muddy” emotions (judgment-laden reactions). (Each scenario within 50 words)
If muddy emotions occur, what should I do? Please provide a brief example.
Tell me the “Polygraph metaphor” in Acceptance and Commitment Therapy. Why is controlling anxiety ineffective? (Answer within 100 words)
Please provide two questions to help me evaluate whether the “Polygraph metaphor” applies to my situation during physical training after spinal cord injury. (Answer within 4 lines)
How can I avoid being influenced by anxiety?
Please summarize my performance in today's responses about “acceptance” to help me better understand acceptance. (Answer within 100 words)

column1: 2. Cognitive Defusion: Viewing thoughts as experiences rather than attempting to change their frequency or content.
column3: Please give an example explaining what “cognitive defusion” means in ACT and how it is practiced. (Answer within 100 words)

column2: Stepping Outside the Framework of Language
column3: Using a short story, explain why ACT encourages people not to view experiences solely through “language.” (Answer within 100 words)
Please propose one question that helps me examine whether I tend to rely on “language” to interpret things in my daily life.
What are “description” and “evaluation” in ACT? Please explain with an example. (Within 100 words)
Please provide examples of common descriptions and evaluations that appear frequently in daily life. (Within 100 words)
Provide four single-sentence questions to test my ability to distinguish between evaluation and description.

column2: Experiential Exercise – Passengers on the Bus
column3: Please give an example to explain the “Passengers on the Bus” exercise in ACT. (Answer within 100 words)
Provide an example to illustrate how I should describe each “passenger.” (Use bullet points; within 100 words)

Provide three questions to guide me through the “Passengers on the Bus” exercise, helping me identify the “passengers” (thoughts) that arise during my life reconstruction after spinal cord injury. (Answer within 100 words)
Based on my responses today, do you think I now better understand cognitive defusion? How should I apply it in the future? (Answer within 80 words)

column1: 3. Contact with the Present Moment: Engaging with and observing present-moment experiences in a non-judgmental manner.
column3: Please use an example to explain what “contact with the present moment” means in ACT. (Answer within 100 words)
Please explain the “Leaves on a Stream” exercise used in ACT for practicing contact with the present moment. (Answer within 100 words)
Provide two questions to guide me through practicing the “Leaves on a Stream” exercise. (Within 100 words)
Using questions, guide me through ACT’s “past–present–future” exercise. (Within 100 words)
How can I remind myself, during life training after spinal cord injury, to stay focused on the present moment rather than on past pain or worries about the future? (Within 5 lines)

column1: 4. Self-as-Context: Recognizing one’s own experiences while maintaining an objective stance, without becoming fused with or attached to them.
column3: Using the ACT chessboard metaphor, explain how to observe the self. (Within 5 lines)
How can I identify my strengths and apply positive labels to myself? Guide my thinking using questions. (Within 50 words)
Building on the previous response, provide two questions that help me view myself—with positive labels—from an “observer perspective.” (Within 4 lines)
Provide two questions that guide me to examine my weaknesses and apply negative labels to myself. (Within 2 lines)
Building on the negative-label response, provide two questions that help me view myself—with negative labels—from an “observer perspective.” (Within 4 lines)
What is the purpose of using positive and negative labels to “observe the self”? (Within 100 words)
Please summarize my responses today and evaluate whether I have gained a basic understanding of contact with the present moment and observing the self. (Within 5 lines)

column1: 5. Values: Choosing to live according to personally meaningful values rather than avoiding experiences.
column3: Tell me how the “Attending Your Own Funeral” metaphor in ACT can help a person discover their values. (Answer within 150 words)
Provide three questions that guide me to clarify my values through the “Attending Your Own Funeral” metaphor. (Answer within 100 words)

Briefly describe the value domains of: (1) Marriage/Partnership/Intimate Relationships, (2) Family Relationships, (3) Friendship/Social Connections, (4) Career/Work, and (5) Personal Growth and Development. (Each within 50 words)
Draw a line after each of the above value domains so I can rank them in importance, with 1 being most important and 5 being least important.
Ask specific questions that help me explain why I chose the top two most important values and assess whether my current behaviors align with these values. (Answer within 100 words)
Explain the ACT values-based question: “What if no one could know?” (Within 50 words)
Based on the values I mentioned today, list two questions that help me reflect on the meaning of “What if no one could know?” (Within 50 words)
Based on my responses today, summarize whether my values have become clearer and provide actionable recommendations for moving forward. (Within 100 words)

column1: 6. Committed Action: Developing goals and strategies based on one’s values and consistently engaging in behavior change that supports a valued life.
column3: My value is ______ (please fill in). I want to develop a long-term goal based on this value. Please ask questions that guide my thinking. (Within 50 words)
I want to set a short-term goal. Please ask questions that guide my thinking. (Within 50 words)
Please explain the ACT metaphor of the “Winding Path” to help me anticipate obstacles that may arise during committed action. (Within 100 words)
Based on the goals I just mentioned, provide two questions that help me consider the possible obstacles, resistance, or thoughts that may arise while pursuing these goals. (Within 100 words)
Please give me some suggestions on how to overcome these obstacles. (Within 100 words)
Provide a concrete example explaining the concept of “breaking dysfunctional patterns” in Acceptance and Commitment Therapy. (Within 80 words)
Provide two questions to guide me in identifying past experiences in which I broke such patterns. (Within 80 words)
Based on my past pattern-breaking experiences, what suggestions do you have for helping me avoid repeating old patterns? (Within 100 words)
Based on my responses today, do you think I am ready to take committed action aligned with my values? (Within 100 words)
